head.title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Lifts Disputed Co-Op Fee

hedline.hl1: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Lifts Disputed Co-Op Fee

body.head.byline: By Motoko Rich (NYT); Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

abstract.p: New York City will stop collecting $50 fee on co-op sales and transfers and will refund nondeed transactions recorded after Jan 1, 2003; plantiffs in class-action suit say they will continue suit against city (S)

block.p: A class-action lawsuit has been filed against the city in an effort to overturn a $50 fee on co-op sales and transfers. But the city said yesterday that it would stop collecting the fees. The lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court last week, claims that the city's Department of Finance illegally charges a $50 fee every time a co-op is sold or transferred. The fee should not apply to co-ops, the suit contends, because co-op sales or transfers involve the exchange of shares in a corporation rather than real estate. Aaron Shmulewitz, a lawyer who is representing the plaintiffs, estimated that the city had collected more than $1 million in such fees. Martha E. Stark, commissioner of the Finance Department, said in a statement that the department had reviewed the fee. ''Accordingly,'' she said, ''Finance will identify those who paid a fee for nondeed transactions after Jan. 1, 2003, and provide refunds where appropriate and will stop collecting fees on these transactions.'' Mr. Shmulewitz said his clients would continue to pursue the suit.
